      int orientation(leetcode.ErectFence587.Point p, leetcode.ErectFence587.Point q, leetcode.ErectFence587.Point r)
      Jarvis algorithm depends on the orientation principle, which finds out that if you are at point p, and you are considering two points q and r which is more counterclockwise, one will return positive and other return negative

      • orientation

        public int orientation(leetcode.ErectFence587.Point p,
                       leetcode.ErectFence587.Point q,
                       leetcode.ErectFence587.Point r)
        Jarvis algorithm depends on the orientation principle, which finds out that if you are at point p, and you are considering two points q and r which is more counterclockwise, one will return positive and other return negative
        See Also:
        book Jarvis, algorithm check every points in the set and find out which one is more counterclockwise and select the top one for the next step and thus cover all the boundary

      • inBetween

        public static boolean inBetween(leetcode.ErectFence587.Point p,
                                leetcode.ErectFence587.Point i,
                                leetcode.ErectFence587.Point q)
        Now, another problem could be that, two points may fall on same counterclockwise related to p, so, we need to find out the first one or the one which sits between p and j and we will do the same processing again. This ensure us that we are not missing anypoints on the boundary
